**The Dao of the Tang and Yu**

The Dao of the Tang and Yu—
It was passed down through abdication, not transmitted.
The kingship of Yao and Shun—
They benefited the realm yet did not hoard it.
Abdication without transmission—
This was the utmost of sageliness.
Benefiting the realm yet not hoarding—
This was the pinnacle of virtue.
Thus, the ancient sages and virtuous ones were such.

When impoverished, they did not covet;
When dying, they did not hoard—
This was the fullness of virtue.
First rectify oneself,
Then rectify the world—
This was the completeness of the Sage’s Way.
Thus, the Dao of the Tang and Yu was abdication.

The Sage, above, served Heaven,
Teaching the people reverence;
Below, served Earth,
Teaching the people renewal [affection];
In season, served the mountains and rivers,
Teaching the people respect;
With renewal, served the ancestral temples,
Teaching the people filiality;
In the Great Academy, the Son of Heaven honored the aged by rank,
Teaching the people fraternal order.
The former sages and latter sages—
Examining the latter to verify the former—
This taught the people the Way of great harmony.

The conduct of Yao and Shun:
Loving the kin, honoring the worthy.
Loving the kin, hence filiality;
Honoring the worthy, hence abdication.
The method of filiality: loving all under Heaven’s people.
The transmission of abdication: no hidden virtue in the age.
Filiality—
This was the crown of virtue.
Abdication—
This was the utmost of righteousness.
The Six Emperors arose in antiquity,
All from this.

Loving the kin while neglecting the worthy—
Virtue yet not righteousness.
Honoring the worthy while abandoning the kin—
Righteousness yet not virtue.

In ancient times, Yu of Pei diligently served his blind father,
And thus was crowned with filiality;
He faithfully served Emperor Yao,
And thus was crowned as a loyal subject.
Loving the kin and honoring the worthy—
This was Yu of Pei.

Yu tamed the floods,
Yi tamed fire,
Hou Ji cultivated the soil,
Sufficient for nourishing life.
Only by conforming to the natural inclinations of flesh and qi,
Nurturing the rectitude of life and fate,
Accepting one’s lot without dying young,
Nurturing life without harm—
Those who knew the governance of all under Heaven
Could thus abdicate the realm.

In ancient times, when Yao and Shun met:
Hearing of Shun’s filiality, [Yao] knew he could nourish the aged of all under Heaven;
Hearing of Shun’s fraternal love, [Yao] knew he could serve the elders of all under Heaven;
Hearing of Shun’s kindness to his brother [and the missing characters]—[Yao] knew he could rule the people.
Thus, as a blind and lame son,
His filiality was profound;
As Yao’s minister,
His loyalty was profound;
When Yao abdicated the realm and entrusted it to him,
He ruled all under Heaven from the south-facing throne—
His kingship was profound.
Thus, Yao’s abdication to Shun was such.

In ancient times, the Sage at twenty was crowned,
At thirty established his household,
At fifty governed all under Heaven,
At seventy retired from office—
His limbs weary, his hearing and sight declining—
He abdicated the realm and entrusted it to the worthy,
Withdrawing to nurture his life.
Thus, it is known that he did not hoard.

The *Yu Odes* say:
*“The great brightness does not emerge,
All things fall into darkness.
When the Sage is not above,
All under Heaven must decay.”*

At the height of governance, the unworthy are nurtured.
At the height of chaos, the worthy are exterminated.
The virtuous advance through this:
Clarifying rites, revering guardianship, delighting in modesty—
This is the teaching of the people.

Gao Yao internally implemented the Five Punishments,
Externally deployed arms—
Light crimes, strict laws—
Yu relied on coercion, Xia on force—
To subdue the unyielding.
Loving yet征 them—
This was the governance of Yu and Xia.
Abdication without transmission was everlasting—
This began with Xia.

In ancient times, Yao was born as Son of Heaven and held the realm.
Sage by fate, virtuous by timing—
He never encountered the worthy.
Though he aligned with the great age,
Divine clarity would follow,
Heaven and Earth would aid him.
Even if the virtuous and sage were present,
The time could not be matched.

In ancient times, Shun dwelled in humble thatch yet was not sorrowful,
Ruled as Son of Heaven yet was not arrogant.
Dwelling in humble thatch yet not sorrowful—
This was knowing one’s fate.
Ruled as Son of Heaven yet not arrogant—
This was not monopolizing.
Seeking the rise of the great person—
This was beauty.

Now, those who wear the virtue of the Sage—
After a few years, they do not wear it;
As rulers and people, they are not arrogant;
Concluding kingship over all under Heaven, they have no doubt.
While in low station, they do not deem the commoner as insignificant;
When holding the realm, they do not deem the realm as weighty.
Holding the realm cannot increase [their virtue],
Losing the realm cannot diminish it.
The utmost of virtue—
Benefiting the realm yet not hoarding.
Abdication—
This is the highest virtue bestowing upon the worthy.

The highest virtue—when the realm has a ruler, the age is enlightened;
To entrust the worthy—when the people rise and emulate, transforming in the Dao.

To transform the people without abdication—never has existed since the birth of humankind.
Thus it is.

The Dao of loyalty and trust—
No deception, no betrayal: this is the utmost loyalty.
No deceit, no ignorance: this is the utmost trust.
When loyalty gathers, one becomes approachable;
When trust gathers, one becomes reviled.
Loyalty and trust gathered yet the people do not trust—never has existed.

Utmost loyalty like earth—transforming all yet without boasting;
Utmost trust like the seasons—all things arrive yet without constraint.
The loyal person knows no deception;
The trustworthy person knows no breach.
The noble one thus—
Does not deceive the living, does not betray the dead.
Enduring for ages without change—this is the utmost loyalty.
Molding yet revealing constancy—this is the utmost trust.
Utmost loyalty knows no deception;
Utmost trust knows no breach—
This is what is spoken of.

Great loyalty does not seek praise;
Great trust does not demand reciprocity.
Not seeking praise yet sufficient to nourish—this is earth.
Not demanding reciprocity yet naturally encountered—this is heaven.
To resemble heaven and earth—
This is what loyalty and trust are spoken of.

Empty promises, yet actions do not follow—
The noble one does not speak thus;
Cold-hearted yet feigning closeness—
The noble one does not act thus.
Thus, to act and compete for the people’s favor—
The noble one does not follow this path.
These three things—
The loyal do not create them, the trustworthy do not commit them.

The Dao of loyalty—
All craftsmen do not weary, yet all are nourished.
The Dao of trust—
All things flourish, yet all virtues stand.
The noble one applies loyalty—
Thus love and attachment gather;
Their words are trustworthy—
Thus they are sincere and received.

Loyalty is the substance of virtue;
Trust is the expectation of righteousness.
Thus, the ancient way of conducting [governance]—
Was thus.

Chéng Zhī heard this and said:
The ancients governing the people—
Sought it in themselves as constant.
If actions are untrustworthy, commands are not obeyed;
If trust does not take root, words are not rejoiced in.
If the people do not obey the ruler’s commands,
Do not trust their words,
Yet still contain virtue—never has existed.

Thus, when the noble one governs the people—
They embody goodness to lead them,
With reverence and caution to guard them,
And where they stand, others follow.
If the ruler embodies goodness,
The people will surpass it.
The ruler in ceremonial cap and robes standing at the eastern stair—
All in the hall are overwhelmed with respect.
The ruler in mourning dress seated in position—
All in the hall are overwhelmed with sorrow.
The ruler in helmet and armor standing in the army—
All in the ranks are overwhelmed with courage.
If the ruler sets the example,
The people will rarely fail to follow.

Yet, their endurance is not profound,
Their weight is not great.
Thus, the noble one’s demands upon themselves are deep.
To seek not at the root yet attack at the branches—
It cannot be attained.
Thus, the noble one values speech—
Not from those who follow superficial trends,
But from those who exhaust the source and return to the root.
If one does not follow its origin,
Does not return to its root,
Nothing can be attained.
The ruler who enjoys success yet does not honor the root—
Their work will not be completed.

The farmer toils for food—
If they do not labor diligently, the granaries will be insufficient.
The scholar speaks grandly yet their words are not acted upon—
Their reputation will not be earned.
Thus, the noble one values speech—
Not from those who follow superficial trends,
But from those who exhaust speech and return to the root.
If one does not follow its origin,
Does not return to its root,
Even if forced, it will not enter.

If the ruler does not act according to the Dao,
The people’s following will be difficult.
Thus, the people can be respectfully guided,
Yet cannot be coerced;
Can be controlled,
Yet cannot be led like cattle.
Thus, the noble one does not value trivial things,
But values harmony with the people.
In order and rank, they advance—
Thus the people desire their advancement to succeed.
In wealth yet humility, they are lowly—
Thus the people desire their wealth to grow.
In nobility yet able to yield—
Thus the people desire their nobility to ascend.
To reverse this Dao—
The people will surely repay with equal measure,
How can one not be cautious?

Thus, the noble one’s repayments are few,
Their demands are not distant—
Privately reflecting upon themselves,
One can know others.
Thus, to desire the people’s love—
One must first love the people;
To desire the people’s respect—
One must first respect the people.
Thus, wisdom in seeking is not hasty—
Their distance from others is not great.
Courage in acting is not resolute—
Their doubts will not go far.
Thus, all things lie in haste.

The *Jun Si* says: **"Only the great and single-minded extol virtue"**—what does this mean? It speaks of haste.

The noble one says: To hasten in action yet not hasten—none can fathom its depth. To urge them to completion, to strengthen their craft; to reiterate with diligence, to refine their words—who among the people would not follow? When it manifests within and expresses outwardly, its sincerity is fixed—who among the people would not believe?

Thus, the constant duty of the superior is to be trusted by the multitude.
The *Ming* says: **"Faithful teacher, completing virtue"**—what does this mean? It says that trust in the multitude can complete virtue.

The nature of the Sage and that of the common person—at birth, none lack aspiration. When nurtured, they remain the same. Though they may not naturally delight in the Way of goodness, repeated practice makes it so. When their breadth and depth grow vast, the Sage cannot be surpassed or rivaled. This is why the people all have innate nature, yet the Sage cannot be emulated.

The *Jun Si* says: **"Support these two, let no harmony be in sound"**—words that displease the Dao. The noble one says: Only what is constant can endure; to persist is difficult.

**"A withered tree for three years—it need not be a banner"**—this speaks of *yín* (vigilance). Thus, the noble one values *yín*.

Heaven bestows great principles to order human relationships. It establishes the duty of ruler and subject, marks the bond of parent and child, and distinguishes the roles of husband and wife. Thus, the petty man disrupts Heaven’s order and defies the great Dao, while the noble one governs human relationships to align with Heaven’s virtue.

The *Da Yu* says: **"My virtue dwells in Heaven’s heart"**—what does this mean? It says that my virtue resides in Heaven’s heart. Thus, the noble one, even at the hearth, yields yet loves the young; in the court, yields yet occupies low rank. His dwelling is not distant.

The petty man does not repay kindness with kindness; the noble one does not repay favor with favor. In a river crossing, the first to board is not as secure as the last. In speech, the one who shouts first is not as triumphant as the one who yields. The noble one says: If one sincerely pardons mistakes, the first to err is absolved, and those who follow are trusted.

Only the noble one’s Dao can be sought near, not borrowed far. In ancient times, the noble one said, **"The Sage’s virtue is Heaven’s"**—what does this mean? It says: Be cautious in seeking within oneself, and thus one can attain harmony with Heaven’s order.

The *Kang Inscript* says: **"Do not return nor clash—King Wen established punishments, crimes without pardon"**—what does this mean? It says that those who do not defy great principles find no heavier model than King Wen’s. Thus, the noble one reverently upholds the six ranks to serve Heaven’s order.

To honor virtue and righteousness, to clarify human relationships—thus one can be a ruler. To abandon wrath and excess, to reform arrogance and victory—this is the duty of those in high station.

Rewards and punishments are the foundation of calamity and blessing; some precede them. Titles and rank are what confirm their legitimacy. Military expeditions are what attack; punishments are what restrain; executions are what eliminate harm. Without the proper path, they cannot be enacted.

Renewal is what makes kinship dear; righteousness is what makes it honored; loyalty is what makes it trusted; learning is what makes it beneficial; teaching is what makes it orderly. Teaching is not altering the Dao; it is guiding. Learning is not changing relationships; it is self-cultivation.

Yu governed his people with human principles; Jie乱 his people with human principles. Jie did not first alter Yu’s people before bringing chaos; Tang did not first alter Jie’s people before bringing order. The Sage’s governance of the people is the people’s own way. Yu’s control of the waters was the water’s own way. Zao Fu’s driving of horses was the horse’s own way. Xi He’s cultivation of the land was the land’s own way. None lack their own way—human principles are the nearest.

Thus, the noble one prioritizes human principles. The discerning emerge to know themselves. Knowing oneself is to know others; knowing others is to know fate; knowing fate is to know the Dao; knowing the Dao is to know action.

From ritual, one knows music; from music, one knows sorrow. There are those who know themselves yet do not know fate, none who know fate yet do not know themselves. There are those who know ritual yet do not know music, none who know music yet do not know ritual.

To take what is good—people will follow, and this is excellence. To walk this measure, only then can one surpass it. To follow constancy, one is steadfast; to examine subtleties, one avoids deviation; to take no sides, one incurs no resentment; to value thought—[illegible].

Things have their proper roles; they are not within teaching’s reach. To teach governance, not the people—governance will not be enacted. Thus, even among these things, what is profound can be taught yet not doubted. What can be taught yet cannot guide the people—then the people cannot be restrained.

To honor ren, cherish loyalty, respect solemnity, and return to ritual—when practiced without contradiction, the heart is nurtured in filial piety. Loyalty and trust grow daily without self-awareness.

The people can be led by the Dao, not made to know it. The people can be guided, not forced. Jie did not assume his people would necessarily rebel, yet they did. What is received but not attained can be followed yet not surpassed.

The ruler of the people restores ritual governance; the people eliminate harm and labor—this is the path of toil. To govern a state without ritual is like [illegible] without [illegible]. Can the people delight in what is not ritual? This is the petty man.

The Way of governance without *ren* yet the people obey—this age is chaotic indeed.

To govern the people is not merely to restore life, but to ensure their desires do not harm *yi* (rightness). To guide the people with love is kindness; to guide them without love is enmity.

The people may be shaped in five ways and made to contend in tens, but only through hundreds will they submit. The virtuous will make the people wealthy, yet wealth does not guarantee harmony. Without harmony, there is no peace; without peace, no joy.

The virtuous will make the people numerous, yet numbers do not guarantee governance. Without governance, there is no order; without order, no tranquility.

Thus, those who rule must first teach and guide. Teach with *li* (ritual), and the people will grow strong. Teach with music, and the people will not quarrel or vie for favor. Teach with eloquence, and the people will grow skilled yet forget their worth. Teach with arts, and the people will vie in the wilds. Teach with craft, and the people will grow stingy. Teach with words, and the people will sigh with distrust. Teach with deeds, and the people will exhaust their strength in pursuit of profit. Teach with stratagem, and the people will grow licentious and benighted, abandoning *li* and renouncing *ren*.

Lead the people with virtue, and they will strive for goodness.

---
*(The ruler, in governance, may debate, deliberate, act from principle, or set examples from without. He must classify these methods. All actions must align with the people’s hearts, for the people’s hearts are constant, and their enduring nature must be sought. Emphasize *yi* and gather principle—this is the essence of this chapter.)*

Those who governed in antiquity led the people only through virtue. Virtue spreads swiftly, like a relay of commands at a post station. Its burden is light, yet its exchange is unnoticed—when lost, it vanishes. Virtue is nothing greater than *li* and music. Govern with harmony and sorrow, and the people cannot be deceived. To reverse this is to err.

Punishments do not reach the noble; *li* does not reach the petty. Aid those who return, and the people’s talents flourish; act without timing, and there is no encouragement.

Without love, there is no closeness; without trust, there is no affection; without reliance, there is no authority; without loyalty, there is no trust; without courage, there is no return to virtue.

Blame them, and the people will submit; correct them, and the people will not be stingy; respect them, and the people will not grieve.

Equality is insufficient for just governance; parity is insufficient for stability; courage is insufficient to overawe the masses; breadth is insufficient to know goodness; decisiveness is insufficient to discern *ren*; killing is insufficient to conquer the people.

When inferiors serve superiors, they follow not their commands but their actions. If the superior loves something, the inferior will love it more.

Thus, virtue can be easily bestowed, and actions can be redirected. There are cases where small benefits turn to great harm, and cases where small harms turn to great benefit.

---
*(Measure these actions, and only then can they be transcended.)*

Thus, the ruler may debate, deliberate, act from principle, or set examples from without. He must classify these methods. All actions must align with the people’s hearts, for the people’s hearts are constant, and their enduring nature must be sought. Emphasize *yi* and gather principle—this is the essence of this chapter.

---
Nature arises from *ming* (fate). Though all have nature, the heart lacks resolve unless acted upon by things, pleased by things, and habituated by things. The *qi* of joy, anger, sorrow, and delight—this is nature. When expressed outwardly, it is shaped by things.

Nature arises from *ming*; *ming* descends from Heaven. The Dao begins with emotion; emotion arises from nature. The beginning is close to emotion; the end is close to *yi*.

Those who know emotion can express it; those who know *yi* can internalize it. Likes and dislikes are nature; what is liked or disliked are things. Goodness and evil are nature; what is good or evil are circumstances.

Nature is the master, yet things shape it. Metal and stone, when struck, produce sound; yet without striking, they remain silent. Though people have nature, the heart remains inactive unless acted upon. The heart has resolve—nothing is impossible—but nature cannot act alone, just as the mouth cannot speak alone.

Oxen are born to grow long; geese are born to stretch their necks—this is their nature. In humans, learning shapes them. All things differ—rigidity is their foundation, shaped by rigidity; gentleness is their constraint, shaped by gentleness.

Within the Four Seas, nature is one. Yet their uses differ, shaped by teaching.

Nature may be stirred, resisted, mingled, disciplined, drawn out, nurtured, or cultivated. What stirs nature are things; what resists it is pleasure; what mingles it is artifice; what disciplines it is *yi*; what draws it out is circumstance; what nurtures it is habit; what cultivates it is the Dao.

What is seen is called things; what pleases is called delight; the power of things is called circumstance; deliberate action is called artifice. *Yi* is the gathering of all goodness. Habit is the means to cultivate nature. The Dao is the Way of all things.

The Dao has four methods, but only human cultivation is truly the Dao. The other three are merely its application.

The *Shijing* (Classic of Poetry), *Shujing* (Classic of Documents), *Liji* (Classic of Rites), and music—all originated from humanity. *Poetry* was composed for a purpose; *Documents* were spoken for a purpose; *Rites* and *Music* were enacted for a purpose.

The sages compared their kinds, deliberated their meanings, observed their sequence, and traced their origins backward. They examined their *yi*, regulated their measures, ordered their emotions, and only then applied them to teaching.

Teaching is the means by which virtue is cultivated within.

Rites arise from emotions, sometimes stirring them; when the occasion arises, they are adapted according to circumstance. Their proper sequence is the Dao of propriety. When sequence is established, it becomes the standard. Adorning one’s bearing is the means to regulate decorum.

The gentleman cherishes his emotions, values propriety, refines decorum, appreciates adornment, delights in the Dao, and takes joy in teaching—thus, he holds it with reverence.

Bowing—what is its purpose? Giving—what is its measure? Silk and cloth—what they signify are trust and proof; their words embody the Dao. Smiling is the shallow tide of ritual; music is its deep tide.

All sounds, when they arise from genuine emotion, move deeply; only then do they resonate within the hearts of others. Hearing laughter, one’s spirit brightens and takes joy. Hearing songs, one’s spirit is transformed and rises in vigor. Listening to the music of *qin* and *se*, one’s heart trembles and sighs. Observing the *Lai* and *Wu* dances, one’s spirit aligns and acts. Observing the *Shao* and *Xia* dances, one’s spirit strives and becomes frugal.

Reciting and contemplating move the heart—
Thus it is. Its duration is long,
Its return to goodness is cautious,
Its expression is measured,
Its cultivation of virtue is steadfast.

The music of Zheng and Wei—
If one hears it and follows, it is not proper.

All ancient music stirs the heart;
Excessive music indulges the senses—
Both teach those who practice them.

The *Lai* and *Wu* music is taken from deeds,
The *Shao* and *Xia* music from emotions.

All supreme music is sorrowful;
Weeping is also sorrow—
Both reach the depths of emotion.

Sorrow and joy are close in nature,
Thus their hearts are not distant.

The stirring of weeping—
Gradually it fades,
Yet its lingering affection remains,
Ending in solemnity.

The stirring of music—
Deep and lingering,
Yet its end is sorrowful,
Lost in contemplation.

All sorrow begins with thought, then becomes grief;
All joy begins with thought, then becomes exultation.

The use of thought is most profound in the heart.
Sighing is its method—
When the voice changes, the heart changes;
When the heart changes, the voice changes too.

Melancholy flows in sorrow,
Joy flows in mirth,
Sounds flow in tones,
Emotions flow in the heart.

Joy transforms into rapture,
Rapture into vigor,
Vigor into song,
Song into contemplation,
Contemplation into action.
Action is the culmination of joy.

Anger becomes sorrow,
Sorrow becomes grief,
Grief becomes sighing,
Sighing becomes withdrawal,
Withdrawal becomes clarity.
Clarity is the end of anger.

For the scholar, seeking the heart is most difficult.
Following what one does brings near attainment—
Yet nothing surpasses the swiftness of music.

Though one may master the art,
If the heart is not mastered, it is not noble.
Seeking the heart requires effort—
If not found, it cannot be attained.

That people cannot feign is known—
If they err ten times, the heart is surely there.
Examining what is visible,
How can emotion be lost?

Examination is the method of propriety.
Propriety is the method of reverence.
Reverence is the measure of things.
Sincerity is the method of benevolence.
Benevolence is the nature’s method.
Nature is born within.
Loyalty is the method of trust.
Trust is the method of emotion.
Emotion arises from nature.

Love encompasses seven aspects,
But only natural love is close to benevolence.
Wisdom encompasses five aspects,
But only the Dao of propriety is close to loyalty.
Hatred encompasses three aspects,
But only hatred of inhumanity is close to righteousness.

Of the four *Daos*, only human cultivation is truly the Dao.

Those whose hearts are restless—
Thought is most intense.
Those whose wisdom is hasty—
Trouble is most severe.
Those whose emotions are extreme—
Sorrow and joy are most profound.
Those who exert their bodies excessively—
Pleasure is most intense.
Those who exhaust their strength—
Gain is most coveted.

The eye’s love of color,
The ear’s delight in sound—
These are the intoxicating *qi* of humanity,
For which people will even die.

If one’s conduct is measured,
Without a sincere heart, it will be superficial.
If one’s conduct is sincere,
Without a steadfast resolve, it will falter.
If one’s speech is clever and persuasive,
Without a humble heart, it will be deceitful.
If one is pleasant and harmonious,
Without a resolute spirit, it will be contemptible.
If one’s actions are swift,
Without guidance, they will fail.
If one’s nature is profound,
Without support, it will be insufficient.

All human pretense is detestable.
Pretense leads to stinginess,
Stinginess leads to calculation,
Calculation leads to isolation from others.

Caution is the method of benevolence.
Yet even in error, it is not evil.
Swiftness is the method of planning—
If there is error, it is blameworthy.
If people are not cautious, they will err—
This is certain.

Human emotions are naturally pleasing.
If one acts from genuine emotion,
Even in excess, it is not evil;
If one acts without genuine emotion,
Even in difficulty, it is not noble.

If one has genuine emotion,
Even in inaction, people will trust them.
Before speech, trust is established—
This is the mark of beautiful emotion.
Before teaching, the people are constant—
This is the mark of innate goodness.
Before rewards, the people are motivated—
This is the mark of contained fortune.
Before punishment, the people are reverent—
This is the mark of inherent awe.

If one is humble yet the people honor them,
This is the mark of virtue.
If one is poor yet the people gather around,
This is the mark of the Dao.
If one finds joy in solitude,
This is the mark of inner ritual.
If one is hated yet cannot be blamed,
This is the mark of understanding righteousness.
If one is blamed yet cannot be hated,
This is the mark of deep benevolence.
If one’s actions do not overstep,
This is the mark of knowing the Dao.
If one hears the Dao and turns upward,
This is the mark of superior exchange.
If one hears the Dao and turns downward,
This is the mark of inferior exchange.
If one hears the Dao and turns inward,
This is the mark of self-cultivation.

This is the mark of humility yet being honored by the people—
This is the mark of virtue.

This is the mark of poverty yet the people gathering around—
This is the mark of the Dao.

If one associates with those of like mind,
They do so through the **Dao**.

If one associates with those of unlike mind,
They do so through the **Way of Adaptation** [or *strategic accommodation*].

If one associates with those who share their joy,
They do so through **virtue**.

If one associates with those who do not share their joy,
They do so through **cunning**.

In governing the household, one seeks ease.
In governing beyond the household, one seeks order.

When delighting others, do not be stingy.
If you must follow with your body, do so.
If you speak of it, make it clear and true—
Do not feign.

In all dealings, avoid excess.
Always ensure there is a proper end.

When summoned for service, do not fear,
And do not speak alone.

In solitude, practice the joys of your elders and forebears.

If there is no great harm,
A little wrong may enter—
But once it is done, do not speak of it again.

In all matters of sorrow and hardship, desire to take them first.
In matters of joy, desire to let others take them first.

The body should be at rest yet not idle,
The mind should be deep yet not withdrawn,
Actions should be bold yet always reach their mark,
Appearance should be strong yet not forced,
The **heart** should be gentle yet harmonious and steady,
Joy should be wise yet without excess,
Delight should be sincere yet purposeful,
Sorrow should be restrained yet not stifled,
Anger should be full yet not petty,
Advancement should be modest yet not insincere,
Retreat should be measured yet not cowardly,
Desires should all be tempered—
And none should be false.

The **gentleman** holds firm to their resolve,
Their mind must be bright and luminous.
Their words must be sincere and trustworthy.
Their guestly rituals must be composed and dignified.
Their sacrificial rites must be reverent and proper.
In mourning, their grief must be deep and lingering.

The **gentleman** takes their body as the master of their mind.

This is the word *quán* (確). Li Ling supplements it as “**heart**” (心), or it may be read as “**appearance**” (容).
Six **Virtues**... this refers to them.
What are the Six **Virtues**?
**Sageliness** (聖) and **Wisdom** (智) are one pair,
**Benevolence** (仁) and **Virtue** (義) are another,
**Loyalty** (忠) and **Trustworthiness** (信) are the third.
**Sageliness** and **Wisdom** are complete.

Abandon sharp intelligence, discard cleverness—
the people benefit a hundredfold.
Abandon cunning, discard profit—
thieves and robbers vanish.
Abandon deceit, discard artifice—
the people return to filial piety and kindness.

Three sayings: one is insufficient for judgment.
Sometimes command, sometimes submit to the grain.

Preserve simplicity, reduce private desires.
The reason the sea is king of the valleys
is that it can be below all valleys—
thus it can be king of the valleys.

When the Sage’s virtue is before the people,
he acts behind them.
When his virtue is above the people,
he speaks below them.

When his virtue is above the people,
the people do not burden him;
when his virtue is before the people,
the people do not harm him.

The world rejoices in advancing without satiation.
Because he does not contend,
the world cannot contend with him.

No guilt is greater than excessive desire,
no blame is deeper than greedy acquisition,
no calamity is worse than not knowing sufficiency.

Knowing sufficiency is true sufficiency—
this is the enduring sufficiency.

Those who assist rulers with the Dao
do not wish to dominate the world with force.

The good are fruitful without boasting,
not seeking strength.

Fruitful without arrogance,
fruitful without pride,
fruitful without vanity—
this is called fruitful without strength.

His affairs are well-loved.

The ancient master of the Way
must be subtle yet profound,
deep beyond recognition—
thus his conduct is praised:

Like winter crossing a river,
like fearing the four neighbors,
like treating guests with sternness,
like releasing tension,
like enduring like simplicity,
like enduring like mud.

Who can endure mud and attain stillness
will gradually become clear.
Who can endure stillness and endure
will gradually attain life.

Preserving this Dao,
one does not desire excess.

Doing leads to ruin,
grasping leads to loss.

Thus the Sage does nothing and so does nothing fail;
does not grasp and so does not lose.

In handling affairs, treat the end as the beginning—
this is how nothing fails.

The Sage desires not to desire,
does not value hard-to-obtain goods,
teaches without teaching,
corrects the people’s errors.

Thus the Sage can assist all things in their natural state
without forcing them.

The Dao is ever non-action—
if lords and kings can guard it,
all things will naturally transform.

When transformation occurs,
govern with nameless simplicity.

This is also knowing sufficiency—
knowing stillness,
all things will naturally settle.

Non-action in action,
non-affairs in affairs,
flavor in flavorlessness.
The small and great are easily confused—
thus difficulties arise.

Therefore the Sage treats difficulty as ease,
and so never encounters difficulty.

All know beauty as beauty—
this is already ugliness.
All know goodness—
this is already not-goodness.

There is non-being generating being,
difficulty and ease forming each other,
long and short defining each other,
high and low filling each other,
sounds harmonizing,
before and after following.

Thus the Sage dwells in non-action,
practices speechless teaching.

Things arise without being initiated,
are done without reliance,
are completed without possession.
Because he does not possess,
he does not lose.

The Dao is ever nameless,
simplicity though subtle—
heaven and earth do not dare to serve it.
If lords and kings can guard it,
all things will naturally come as guests.

The people do not command it—

When the **nine layers** are piled high,

**Return** is the **movement** of the **Way**.

All things under heaven **arise** from **being**,

**Rushing** and **herding** it,

**Gold and jade** **fill** the **hall**,

**Wealth and arrogance** **invite** **calamity**.
**Achievement** **completed**, **withdraw**—
this is the **Way** of Heaven.

*"The virtuous conduct of King Wen, all nations take him as trustworthy."* (仪刑文王，万邦作孚)

◆ **记** The Master said: To love the virtuous is like loving black garments, to hate what is evil is like hating **Perpetrator of the Alley** (巷伯), then **rank** (爵) will not be **desecrated** (渎) and the people will **aspire** (作愿); **punishment** (刑) will not be **tested** (试) upon them, yet the people will all **submit** (服).
The *Great Odes* (《大雅》) say:
*"The virtuous conduct of King Wen, all nations take him as trustworthy."* (仪刑文王，万国作孚)

---

**简** The Master said: A ruler above can be **aspired to** (可望) and **known** (知), a subject below can be **imitated** (可类) and **followed** (志), then the **prince** (君) will not **doubt** (疑) his ministers, nor will ministers be **confused** (惑) by their prince.
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"The virtuous gentleman, his **conduct** (仪) is without **fault** (不忒)."*
The *Inscriptions of Yin* (《尹诰》) say:
*"Only Yin Yun and Tang had **one virtue/power** (一德)."*

◆ The Master said: A ruler above can be **aspired to** (可望) and **known** (知), a subject below can be **described** (可述) and **followed** (志), then the **prince** (君) will not **doubt** (疑) his ministers, nor will ministers be **confused** (惑) by their prince.
The *Inscriptions of Yin* (《尹吉》) say:
*"Only Yin Gong and Tang had **one virtue/power** (一德)."*
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"The virtuous gentleman, his **conduct** (仪) is without **fault** (不忒)."*

---

**简** The Master said: If the ruler above **doubts** (疑), then the people below will be **confused** (惑); if the subject below is **hard to understand** (难知), then the prince will **long labor** (长劳).
Thus, one who **governs the people** (君民) must **display** (章) what is good to show the people’s desires, **be cautious** (慎) of what is evil to **restrain** (御) the people’s **excesses** (淫), then the people will not be **confused** (惑).
When ministers **serve** (事) their prince, they do not **speak of** (言) what they cannot do, nor do they **refuse** (辞) what they can do, then the prince will not **labor** (劳).
The *Great Odes* (《大雅》) say:
*"The **Heavenly Sovereign** (上帝) is **stern and upright** (板板), the people below finally **submit** (卒疸)."*
The *Small Odes* (《小雅》) say:
*"It is not **his** (匪其) **cessation** (止共), but the **prince’s** (惟王) **decree** (邛)."*

◆ **记** The Master said: If the ruler above **doubts** (疑), then the people below will be **confused** (惑); if the subject below is **hard to understand** (难知), then the prince will **long labor** (长劳).
Thus, one who **governs the people** (君民) must **display** (章) what is good to show the people’s **customs** (俗), **be cautious** (慎) of what is evil to **restrain** (御) the people’s **excesses** (淫), then the people will not be **confused** (惑).
When ministers **perform their duties** (仪行), they do not **repeat words** (重辞), nor do they **aid** (援) what they cannot reach, nor do they **burden** (烦) what they do not know, then the prince will not **labor** (劳).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"The **Heavenly Sovereign** (上帝) is **stern and upright** (板板), the people below finally **submit** (卒疸)."*
The *Small Odes* (《小雅》) say:
*"It is not **his** (匪其) **cessation** (止共), but the **prince’s** (惟王) **decree** (邛)."*

---

**简** The Master said: The people take their prince as their **heart** (心), the prince takes the people as his **body** (体).
If the **heart** (心) is **good** (好), then the **body** (体) will be **at ease** (安).
If the prince is **good** (好), then the people will **aspire** (欲).
Thus, if the **heart** (心) is **ruined** (废) by the **body** (体), the prince will **perish** (亡) with the people.
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"Who **holds** (秉) the state’s **establishment** (国成), yet does not **set himself as its standard** (为正), finally **wearies** (卒劳) the people."*

The *Ode of the Prince* (《君雅》) says:
*"In the **summer’s** (夏) **heat** (日暑) and **rain** (雨), the **common folk** (小民) only **say** (惟日) **grievance** (怨)."*

◆ **记** The Master said: The people take their prince as their **heart** (心), the prince takes the people as his **body** (体).
If the **heart** (心) is **upright and settled** (庄), then the **body** (体) will be **relaxed** (舒); if the **heart** (心) is **solemn and reverent** (肃), then the **demeanor** (容) will be **respectful** (敬).
If the **heart** (心) is **good** (好), then the **body** (身) will certainly be **at ease** (安).
If the prince **loves** (好) what is good, then the people will certainly **aspire** (欲).
If the **heart** (心) is **ruined** (废) by the **body** (体), it is also **injured** (伤) by the **body** (体); if the prince **perishes** (亡) with the people, he is also **preserved** (存) by them.
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"Once there were **earlier worthies** (先正), their **words** (言) were **clear and pure** (明且清).
The state **thus found peace** (以宁), the **capital cities** (都邑) **were established** (以成), the **common folk** (庶民) **thrived** (以生).
Who could **hold** (秉) the state’s **establishment** (国成), yet does not **set himself as its standard** (为正), finally **wearies** (卒劳) the people."*

The *Ode of the Prince* (《君雅》) says:
*"In the **summer’s** (夏) **heat** (日暑) and **rain** (雨), the **common folk** (小民) only **say** (惟曰) **grievance** (怨);
In the **winter’s** (资冬) **cold** (祁寒), the **common folk** (小民) also only **say** (惟曰) **grievance** (怨)."*

---

**简** The Master said: If the ruler above **loves** (好) **virtue/power** (仁), then those below will **strive to emulate** (争先) it.
Thus, one who **governs the people** (长民) must **display** (章) his **intentions** (志) and **make them clear** (昭) to the people, then the people will **direct their conduct** (致行己) to **please** (说) their ruler.
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"One who **has** (有) **virtue/power** (觉德行), all four directions will **submit** (顺) to him."*

◆ **记** The Master said: If the ruler above **loves** (好) **virtue/power** (仁), then those below will **strive to emulate** (争先) him.
Thus, one who **governs the people** (长民) must **display** (章) his **intentions** (志), **establish** (贞) **teachings** (教), and **honor** (尊) **virtue/power** (仁), to **show** (子) that he **loves** (爱) the people, then the people will **direct their conduct** (致行己) to **please** (说) their ruler.
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"One who **has** (有) **virtue/power** (梏德行), all four nations will **submit** (顺) to him."*

---

**简** The Master said: After **Yu** (禹) **ascended to rule** (立), three years passed, and the people **followed** (以) the **Dao/Way** of **virtue/power** (仁道).
Was it **necessary** (必) that he **fully exhausted** (尽) **virtue/power** (仁)?
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"The **trustworthy virtue/power** (之孚) of King Cheng, the **pattern** (式) for the **lower lands** (下土)."*
The *Instructions of Lu* (《吕刑》) say:
*"If **one person** (一人) has **blessing** (庆), then **millions of people** (兆民) will **rely** (赖) upon him."*

◆ **记** The Master said: After **Yu** (禹) **ascended to rule** (立), three years passed, and the people **followed** (以) **virtue/power** (仁) and **completed** (遂) it.
Was it **necessary** (必) that he **fully exhausted** (尽) **virtue/power** (仁)?
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"**Brilliant** (赫赫) **Teacher Yin** (师尹), the people **all** (具) **look up to** (尔瞻) you."*
The *Instructions of Fu* (《甫刑》) say:
*"If **one person** (一人) has **blessing** (庆), then **millions of people** (兆民) will **rely** (赖) upon him."*
The *Great Odes* (《大雅》) say:
*"The **trustworthy virtue/power** (之孚) of King Cheng, the **pattern** (式) for the **lower lands** (下土)."*

---

**简** The Master said: When those below **serve** (事) those above, they do not **follow** (从) the **reasoning** (所以) behind his **commands** (命), but **follow** (从) his **actions** (行).
If the ruler above **loves** (好) this **thing** (物), then those below will certainly **exceed** (有甚) in it.
Thus, the **prince’s** (上) **preferences** (好) and **aversions** (恶) must be **cautiously considered** (不可不慎), for they are the **people’s model** (表).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"**Brilliant** (赫赫) **Teacher Yin** (师尹), the people **all** (具) **look up to** (尔瞻) you."*

◆ **记** The Master said: When those below **serve** (事) those above, they do not **follow** (从) his **orders** (所令), but **follow** (从) his **actions** (所行).
If the ruler above **loves** (好) this **thing** (物), then those below will certainly **exceed** (有甚) in it.
Thus, the **prince’s** (上) **preferences** (好) and **aversions** (恶) must be **cautiously considered** (不可不慎), for they are the **people’s model** (表).

---

**简** The Master said: One who **governs the people** (长民), if his **clothing and carriage** (衣服) do not **change** (改), and his **composure** (从容) has **constancy** (常), then the people’s **virtue/power** (德) will be **unified** (一).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"His **composure** (容) does not **change** (改), his **utterances** (出言) have **instruction** (训), the people **trust** (信) in him."*

---

chunks.translated_text:
The Master said:
One who **governs the people** (长民), if his **clothing and carriage** (衣服) do not **waver** (贰), and his **composure** (从容) has **constancy** (常), and he **harmonizes** (齐) his people with it, then the people’s **virtue/power** (德) will be **unified** (一).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"The noble citizens of the capital, their fox-fur robes bright and yellow,
Their **composure** (容) does not **change** (改), their **words** (出言) have **order** (章).
They **return** (行) to the **rites of Zhou** (周), the **hope of all the people** (万民所望)."*

---

The Master said:
If the **great ones** (大人) do not **cherish** (亲) those they **esteem** (所贤), but **trust** (信) those they **deem unworthy** (所贱),
Then the people **will grow weary of instruction** (教此以失), and **will be burdened by governance** (民此以烦).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"They seek my **rites** (则), as if they could not **obtain** (得) them.
They grasp my **enmity** (仇仇), yet they cannot **overcome** (力) me."*
The *Ode of the Prince* (《君陈》) says:
*"Before seeing the **sage** (圣), it is as if they could not **see** (见) him.
Though they have seen the **sage** (圣), they cannot **follow** (迪) him."*

---

The Master said:
If **great ministers** (大臣) are not **cherished** (不亲), then their **loyalty and respect** (忠敬) will be **insufficient** (不足), and their **wealth and honor** (富贵) will have **exceeded** (已过).
If the **state is not at peace** (邦家之不宁), then the **great ministers** (大臣) will not **govern properly** (不治), and **low-ranking ministers** (亵臣) will **take advantage** (托).
Thus, the **great ministers** (大臣) must not be **neglected** (不可不敬), for they are the **people’s model** (蕝).
Hence, the **ruler** (君) should not **use minor matters to plan major ones** (不与小谋大), lest the **great ministers** (大臣) **complain** (不怨).
The **Sacrificial Public’s** (祭公) **final instructions** (顾命) said:
*"Do not **use minor matters to ruin major undertakings** (以小谋败大作),
Do not **favor close attendants** (嬖御) and thereby **alienate the Queen Mother** (疾庄后),
Do not **favor close attendants** (嬖御) and thereby **alienate the great officers** (疾大夫、卿士)."*

---

The Master said:
If **great ministers** (大臣) are not **cherished** (不亲), the people will not be **at ease** (不宁).
Then their **loyalty and respect** (忠敬) will be **insufficient** (不足), and their **wealth and honor** (富贵) will have **exceeded** (已过).
If **great ministers** (大臣) are not **governed properly** (不治), then **close-ranking ministers** (迩臣) will **consort together** (比).
Thus, **great ministers** (大臣) must not be **neglected** (不可不敬), for they are the **people’s model** (表);
And **close-ranking ministers** (迩臣) must not be **reckoned lightly** (不可不慎), for they are the **people’s Dao/Way** (道).
The **ruler** (君) should not **use minor matters to plan major ones** (以小谋大),
Nor **speak of distant matters to those nearby** (以远言近),
Nor **plot against outsiders from within** (以内图外).
Then the **great ministers** (大臣) will not **complain** (怨),
The **close-ranking ministers** (迩臣) will not **be resentful** (疾),
And **distant ministers** (远臣) will not **be obstructed** (蔽).
The **Leaf Public’s** (叶公) **final instructions** (顾命) said:
*"Do not **use minor matters to ruin major undertakings** (以小谋败大作),
Do not **favor close attendants** (嬖御) and thereby **alienate the people’s resentment** (人疾庄后),
Do not **favor close attendants** (嬖御) and thereby **alienate the officers’ resentment** (士疾庄士、大夫、卿士)."*

---

The Master said:
One who **governs the people** (长民) should **teach** (教) them with **virtue/power** (德) and **harmonize** (齐) them with **rites** (礼), then the people will have **a heart to emulate** (有劝心).
If he **teaches** (教) them with **laws** (政) and **harmonizes** (齐) them with **punishments** (刑), then the people will have **a heart to evade** (有免心).
Thus, with **kindness** (慈) he **loves** (以爱) them, then the people will **be close to him** (有亲).
With **trustworthiness** (信) he **binds** (以结) them, then the people will not **turn against him** (不倍).
With **reverence** (恭) he **approaches** (以莅) them, then the people will have **a heart to yield** (有逊心).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"Our **great ministers** (大夫) are **reverent** (恭) and **frugal** (俭), none dare to be **extravagant** (敛)."*
The *Ode of the Prince* (《吕刑》) says:
*"The **common people** (苗民) do not **use** (匪用) **commands** (命), they are **restrained** (制) by **punishments** (刑).
Only the **five cruel punishments** (五虐之刑) are established as **law** (法)."*

---

The Master said:
If **governance** (政) does not **take effect** (不行), and **teaching** (教) does not **succeed** (不成), then **punishments** (刑罚) will not be **sufficient to deter** (足耻), and **titles and rewards** (爵禄) will not be **sufficient to encourage** (足劝).
Thus, the **ruler above** (上) cannot **use punishments lightly** (亵刑) and **devalue titles** (轻爵).
The *Kang Inscriptions* (《康诰》) say:
*"Reverently **make clear** (明) your **punishments** (罚)."*
The *Ode of the Prince* (《吕刑》) says:
*"**Broadcast** (播) the **punishments** (刑) so that they may be **followed** (迪)."*

---

The Master said:
The **ruler’s words** (王言) are like **silk threads** (丝),
Their **emergence** (出) is like **reeling silk** (缗).
The **ruler’s words** (王言) are like **plain silk** (素),
Their **emergence** (出) is like **woven silk** (绋).
Thus, the **great ones** (大人) do not **promote idle talk** (倡流).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"Be **cautious** (慎) in your **utterances** (出话), be **reverent** (敬) in your **demeanor** (威仪)."*

---

The Master said:
What **can be spoken** (可言) but cannot be **done** (不可行), the **gentleman** (君子) will not **speak** (弗言).
What **can be done** (可行) but cannot be **spoken** (不可言), the **gentleman** (君子) will not **do** (弗行).
Then the people’s **words** (言) will not **endanger** (危) their **actions** (行),
And their **actions** (行) will not **endanger** (危) their **words** (言).
The *Book of Songs* (《诗》) says:
*"Be **virtuous and cautious** (淑慎) in your **conduct** (止), do not **err** (愆) in **rites** (仪)."*

---

The Master said:
The **gentleman** (君子) **guides** (道) people with **words** (言), yet **constrains** (禁) them with **actions** (行).
Thus, **words** (言) must **consider** (虑) their **ultimate consequences** (所终),

The water is near to man yet drowns him,
Virtue is easy to trifle with yet hard to draw near—
Easy to drown men.

The mouth wastes words and troubles,
Easy to speak, hard to retract—
Easy to drown men.

The people are hemmed in by men,
Yet harbor base hearts—
To be revered, not slighted—
Easy to drown men.

Thus, the gentleman must be cautious.

The *Great Jia* says:
*"Do not overstep your decree to bring ruin upon yourself;
Like a drawn bowstring, if you return to your measure, it will relax."*

The *Fu Command* says:
*"From the mouth comes shame,
From armor and helmets, war arises,
From garments stored in chests,
From weapons, one reflects upon oneself."*

The *Great Jia* says:
*"When Heaven inflicts calamity, it may be averted;
When one brings calamity upon oneself, it cannot be delayed."*

The *Yin Ji* says:
*"The Duke of Yin followed Heaven,
Manifest in the Western Domain;
From Xia to Zhou, the end was reached—
The ministers also met their end."*

---

When Duke Mu of Lu consulted Zisi,
Duke Mu asked Zisi: *"How may one be called a loyal minister?"*
Zisi replied: *"He who constantly speaks of his lord’s faults may be called a loyal minister."*

The duke took no pleasure in this, bowed, and dismissed him.

Cheng Sun Yi entered, and the duke said: *"Just now, I asked Zisi about loyal ministers. He said, ‘He who constantly speaks of his lord’s faults may be called a loyal minister.’ I am perplexed and do not understand it."*

Cheng Sun Yi said: *"Ah, how excellent his words are!
There have been those who killed themselves for their lord’s sake—
But never one who constantly spoke of his lord’s faults.

Those who kill themselves for their lord’s sake seek rewards and rank.
Those who constantly speak of their lord’s faults shun rewards and rank.
To uphold righteousness while shunning rewards and rank—
If not Zisi, whom else have I heard speak thus?"*

*"Prosperity and adversity come in their time."*

The **Way** of Heaven and humanity has its allotments.
To discern the allotments of Heaven and humanity is to know what to act upon.

There may be the person, yet lack the age—
Even the virtuous cannot act.
If the age is right, what difficulty could there be?

Shun plowed at **Lìshān** and molded clay by the **Hé**’s banks,
Yet rose to become Son of Heaven—he met **Yáo**.
**Shào Yóu** wore a child’s robe and cap of mourning,
Abandoned his labor to aid the Son of Heaven—he met **Wǔdīng**.
**Lǚ Wàng** guarded the **Zāng-Jí** ferry and fought at **Jiémén**’s thorny fields,
At seventy butchered cattle in **Cháogē**, yet was honored as the Son of Heaven’s teacher—he met **Zhōu Wén**.
**Guān Yíwú**, bound and imprisoned, freed from shackles became a minister to the lords—he met **Qí Huán**.
**Bǎilǐ Xī** presented five rams, herding cattle as a commoner,
Freed from labor became a court official—he met **Qín Mù**.
**Sūn Shū** was thrice exiled for **Héng Sī**’s minor office,
Yet returned to become **Língyīn**—he met **Chǔ Zhuāng**.

At first, they concealed their brilliance; later, their fame spread—
Not because their virtue increased.
**Zǐxū** had many merits before, yet was executed afterward—
Not because his wisdom declined.
A fine steed was trapped in **Zhāngshān**, a swift one buried in **Shàojí**—
Not because their strength was lost.
To roam the four seas, to reach a thousand **lǐ**—
It was fate to meet **Zàofǔ**.

Meeting or not meeting—it is **Heaven**.
Action does not ensure success, so though in adversity, one does not complain.
Seclusion is not for fame, so though unrecognized, one does not begrudge.
**Zhǐlán** grows in the forest—
Though unseen, its fragrance does not fade.
Without opening, it is more treasured than mountain jade—
Not because its goodness is hidden within itself.
Prosperity and adversity come in their time; virtue and conduct remain one.

Praise and blame come from others—
Listen to them as **Yìmǔ** does, distinguishing black and white without hesitation.
Prosperity and adversity come in their time; darkness and clarity do not repeat.

Thus, the **Junzi** strives to reflect inward.

**Chapter 1**
When **ren** manifests inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.
When it does not manifest inwardly, it is called conduct.
When **yì** manifests inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.
When it does not manifest inwardly, it is called conduct.
When **lǐ** manifests inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.
When it does not manifest inwardly, it is called conduct.
When wisdom manifests inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.
When it does not manifest inwardly, it is called conduct.
When **sainthood** manifests inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.
When it does not manifest inwardly, it is called the **Way** of virtue.

**Chapter 2**
The five courses of virtue, harmonized, are called **virtue**.
The four courses harmonized are called **goodness**.
**Goodness** is the **Way** of humanity.
**Virtue** is the **Way** of Heaven.

The **Junzi**, without inner turmoil, has no inner wisdom;
Without inner wisdom, has no inner joy;
Without inner joy, is not at ease;
Not at ease, does not find happiness;
Without happiness, lacks **virtue**.

---
**Chapter 3**
When the five courses all manifest inwardly and are practiced in due measure,
That is called the **Junzi**.
The **shì** who aspires to the **Junzi’s Way** is called a **志士**.

What is **good** but not practiced is not near;
What is **virtue** but not aspired to cannot be achieved;
What is wisdom but not pondered cannot be attained.
Pondering without precision does not discern;
Pondering without depth does not attain;
Pondering without clarity does not manifest.
[If it does not manifest, one is not at ease;]
Not at ease, [one] does not find happiness;
Without happiness, [one] lacks **virtue**.

**Chapter 4**
Without **ren**, pondering cannot be clear.
Without wisdom, pondering cannot be profound.
[Without **ren** and without wisdom,]
Before seeing the **Junzi**, the heart cannot be troubled;
After seeing the **Junzi**, the heart cannot rejoice.

*The **Shī** says:*
*"Before seeing the **Junzi**, the heart was troubled;
Now that I have seen and observed him,
My heart finds joy."*
This is what is meant.

Without **ren**, pondering cannot be clear.
Without **sainthood**, pondering cannot be light.
Without **ren** and without **sainthood**,
Before seeing the **Junzi**, the heart cannot be anxious;
After seeing the **Junzi**, the heart cannot be at peace.

---
**Chapter 5**
The pondering of **ren** is clear;
Precision brings discernment;
Discernment brings ease;
Ease brings warmth;
Warmth brings joy;
Joy brings reverence;
Reverence brings affection;
Affection brings a jade-like complexion;
A jade-like complexion takes form;
Form manifests **ren**.

---
**Chapter 6**
The pondering of wisdom is profound;
Profoundness brings attainment;
Attainment brings no forgetting;
No forgetting brings clarity;
Clarity brings seeing the virtuous;
Seeing the virtuous brings a jade-like complexion;
A jade-like complexion takes form;
Form manifests wisdom.

---
**Chapter 7**
The pondering of **sainthood** is light;
Lightness takes form;
Form brings no forgetting;
No forgetting brings acuity;
Acuity brings hearing the **Junzi’s Way**;
Hearing the **Junzi’s Way** brings a jade-like voice;
A jade-like voice takes form;
Form manifests **sainthood**.

---
**Explication of Chapter 7**
*"The pondering of **sainthood** is light."*
Pondering is pondering **Heaven**; lightness is exalted.
*"Lightness takes form."*
Form is the manifestation of what is pondered.
When **Zǐsī** of **Yǒuxià** was light as **Zhì**, the commoner was like one severed;
When **Zǐsī** of **Yǒuxià** saw him as severed, the commoner was like flowing water.
This speaks to the lightness of his pondering.
*"No forgetting brings acuity."*
Acuity is **sainthood** stored in the ears—
Like **Kǒngzǐ** hearing the light drumming and attaining **Lú**’s thatched hall.
*"Acuity brings hearing the **Junzi’s Way**."*
The **Way** is **Heaven’s Way**; hearing the **Junzi’s Way** is knowing it with the ears.
*"Hearing the **Junzi’s Way** brings a jade-like voice."*

「□□□□□□ while beautiful, is the **sainthood** stored in the ears—
knowing its **so** (as) **so** (that) with hearing the **Way**.
*"A jade-like voice then takes form."*
□□□□.
*"Form then brings **sainthood**."*
□□□□ **sainthood**.

**[Scripture 8]** *"[The turtle-dove perches on the mulberry tree, its young are seven in number].
The virtuous person, the **Junzi**, their conduct is singular]."*
To be singular, then one can become a **Junzi**—
cultivate their solitude with care.
◆16 *"[The swallow flies with gentle wings, its feathers disordered.
That child departs for marriage, sent far into the wild].
Gazing and sighing, unable to reach them, tears fall like rain."*
To have disordered feathers, then one can reach profound sorrow.
The **Junzi** must guard their 17 solitude.

**[Explication 8]** *"The turtle-dove perches on the mulberry tree."*
This is **uprightness** (直).
*"Its young are seven in number."*
The turtle-dove has but two young—
yet it says "seven," a poetic metaphor.
*"The virtuous person, the **Junzi**, their conduct is singular."*
The virtuous person is **sainthood** (圣),
conduct is **virtue/power** (德).
This speaks of their **virtue/power** (德) in action,
unified in heart.
*"To be singular, then one can become a **Junzi**."*
To be singular is to make many one;
to make many one is to unify the **Five Phases** (五).
*"The **Junzi** must guard their solitude."*
To guard their solitude is to set aside the **Five Phases** (五)
and focus solely on their heart.
Only then can they be singular;
singularity is the **Five Phases** (五) unified in heart.
Then they attain it.
Singularity is **virtue/power** (德) fulfilled.
**Virtue/power** (德) is like **Heaven** (天);
**Heaven** (天) is **virtue/power** (德) fulfilled.
*"The swallow flies with gentle wings, its feathers disordered."*
The swallow is a metaphor for **uprightness** (直),
speaking of its **upright** (直) yet sorrowful parting.
When its **qi** (氣) transforms,
it is not in its feathers alone.
*"That child departs for marriage, sent far into the wild.
Gazing and sighing, unable to reach them, tears fall like rain."*
To have disordered feathers, then one can reach profound sorrow.
This speaks of **attainment** (至).
Disordered feathers mean
not in mourning robes and mourning headbands—
only when not in mourning robes and headbands
can one reach profound sorrow.
This sorrow is the **Five Phases** (五) within,
not in the external forms.
*"This is called solitude."*
Solitude is to set aside the body.

**[Scripture 9]** The **Junzi** in doing good,
has both beginning and end.
The **Junzi** in cultivating **virtue/power** (德),
has beginning but no end.

**[Explication 9]** *"The **Junzi** in doing good, has both beginning and end."*
This means aligning with the body from beginning to end.
*"The **Junzi** in cultivating **virtue/power** (德), has beginning but no end."*
To have beginning is to align with the body from the start;
to have no end is to set aside the body
and focus solely on the heart.

**[Scripture 10]** When the golden voice resonates and the jade-like voice responds,
this is the **person of virtue/power** (有德者).
◆The golden voice is **goodness** (善);
the jade-like voice is **sainthood** (圣).
**Goodness** (善) is the **Way** of humanity (人道);
**virtue/power** (德) is **Heaven’s Way** (天道).
Only the **person of virtue/power** (有德者)
can then produce the golden voice and the jade-like response.

**[Explication 10]** *"When the golden voice resonates and the jade-like voice responds."*
………
………
□□□□ by **virtue/power** (德) being profound.
**Goodness** (善) is what has affairs (事),
able to combine **yang** and **yin** in many ways.
Thus **goodness** (善) is **Dao/Way** (道).
*"**Virtue/power** (德) is **Heaven’s Way** (天道)."*
**Heaven’s Way** (天道) is **so** (as) **so** (that) which is beautiful yet unattached.
*"Only the **person of virtue/power** (有德者) can then produce the golden voice and the jade-like response."*
The golden voice and jade-like response
are the **Dao/Way** (道) in motion,
and the **person of virtue/power** (有德者) manifests **goodness** (善) externally through form.
**[Scripture 11]** Without **acuity** (聪) there is no **clarity** (明),
without **clarity** (明) there is no **sainthood** (圣),
without **sainthood** (圣) there is no **wisdom** (智),
without **wisdom** (智) there is no **benevolence** (仁),
without **benevolence** (仁) there is no **tranquility** (安),
without **tranquility** (安) there is no **joy** (乐),
without **joy** (乐) there is no **virtue/power** (德).
◆**[7]** **[Explication 11]** *"Without **acuity** (聪) there is no **clarity** (明)."*
**Acuity** (聪) is **sainthood** (圣) stored in the ears;
**clarity** (明) is **wisdom** (智) stored in the eyes.
**Acuity** (聪) is the beginning of **sainthood** (圣);
**clarity** (明) is the beginning of **wisdom** (智).
Thus it is said.
*"Without **acuity** and **clarity**, there is no **sainthood** and **wisdom**."*
**Sainthood** (圣) and **wisdom** (智) must come from **acuity** (聪) and **clarity** (明).
**Sainthood** (圣) begins with **Heaven** (天);
**wisdom** (智) begins with humanity (人).
**Sainthood** (圣) is exalted;
**wisdom** (智) is broad.
*"Without **wisdom** (智), there is no **benevolence** (仁)."*
**Benevolence** (仁) without **wisdom** (智) is what love?
This speaks of **benevolence** (仁) relying on **wisdom** (智) to act.
*"Without **benevolence** (仁), there is no **tranquility** (安)."*
**Benevolence** (仁) brings **tranquility** (安)—
this is **Heaven’s Way** (天道).
*"Without **tranquility** (安), there is no **joy** (乐)."*
**Tranquility** (安) is to align with the body and be at ease;
only then can one find **joy** (乐).
*"Without **joy** (乐), there is no **virtue/power** (德)."*
**Joy** (乐) is the flow of **qi** (氣),
naturally forgetting blockages.
To forget blockages is the **virtue/power** (德) attained;
**joy** (乐) comes only after **virtue/power** (德).

**[Scripture 12]** Without **change** (变), there is no **delight** (悦),
without **delight** (悦), there is no **sorrow** (戚),
without **sorrow** (戚), there is no **affection** (亲),
without **affection** (亲), there is no **love** (爱),
without **love** (爱), there is no **benevolence** (仁).
◆**[Explication 12]** *"Without **change** (变), there is no **delight** (悦)."*
**Change** (变) is **striving** (勉),
the **qi** of **benevolence** (仁).
**Change** (变) brings **delight** (悦).
*"Without **delight** (悦), there is no **sorrow** (戚)."*
**Delight** (悦) brings **sorrow** (戚) for what is sorrowful.
*"Without **sorrow** (戚), there is no **affection** (亲)."*
**Sorrow** (戚) brings **affection** (亲) for it.
*"Without **affection** (亲), there is no **love** (爱)."*
**Affection** (亲) brings **love** (爱) for it.
*"Without **love** (爱), there is no **benevolence** (仁)."*
**Love** (爱) brings **benevolence** (仁).

**[Scripture 13]** Without **uprightness** (直), there is no **boldness** (肆),
without **boldness** (肆), there is no **firmness** (果),
without **firmness** (果), there is no **simplicity** (简),
without **simplicity** (简), there is no **action** (行),
without **action** (行), there is no **righteousness** (义).
◆**[Explication 13]** *"Without **uprightness** (直), there is no **boldness** (肆)."*
**Uprightness** (直) is to straighten the heart—
the **qi** of **righteousness** (义).
**Uprightness** (直) brings **boldness** (肆).
**Boldness** (肆) is to complete it;
not receiving from the common people,
but receiving from **Mèngrèn** (孟贲),
this is not yet **boldness** (肆).
*"Without **boldness** (肆), there is no **firmness** (果)."*
**Firmness** (果) is to not fear—
no obstructions in the heart □□.

「“**Not Firmness, there is no Simplicity** (不果不简).”
**Simplicity** (简) is to not let the small harm the great,
to not let the light harm the weighty.

*"**Without Simplicity, there is no Action** (不简不行)."*
**Action** (行) is to act in accordance with its [proper] nature.

*"**Without Action, there is no Righteousness** (不行不义)."*
This is **Righteousness** (义).

**[Scripture 14]** Without **distance** (远), there is no **reverence** (敬),
without **reverence** (敬), there is no **solemnity** (严),
without **solemnity** (严), there is no **honor** (尊),
without **honor** (尊), there is no **deference** (恭),
without **deference** (恭), there is no **propriety** (礼).
◆**[Explication 14]** *"Without **distance** (远), there is no **reverence** (敬)."*
**Distance** (远) of the heart—this is the **propriety** (礼) **qi**.
If one is close in quality, one cannot [fully] grasp it;
thus, one must **distance oneself** to attain **reverence** (敬).
**Distance** (远) is to stir the **reverence** (敬) heart,
to cultivate the **reverence** (敬) heart.
To lead with the left and feed with the right is not yet **reverence** (敬).

*"Without **reverence** (敬), there is no **solemnity** (严)."*
**Solemnity** (严) is like **accumulation** (积).
**Accumulation** (积) is the **reverence** (敬) that has built up.

*"Without **solemnity** (严), there is no **honor** (尊)."*
**Solemnity** (严) brings **honor** (尊) to oneself.

*"Without **honor** (尊), there is no **deference** (恭)."*
**Deference** (恭) is to [use] **reverence** (敬) above and **propriety** (礼) below.

**Deference** (恭) brings **propriety** (礼), as this is the **propriety** (礼) **qi**.

one is called **not perceptive** (不聪).
Never having seen a **virtuous one** (贤人),
one is called **not enlightened** (不明).
Having heard the **Dao** of the **junzi** but not knowing it,
one is called **not sagely** (不圣).
Having seen a **virtuous one** but not knowing of their **virtue/power** (有德),
one is called **not wise** (不智).

thus they are called **not perceptive** (不聪).

*"Never having seen a **virtuous one**, one is called **not enlightened** (不明)."*

thus they are called **not enlightened** (不明).

thus they are called **not wise** (不智).

◆**[Explication 16]** *"To hear and know, this is **sagacity** (圣)."*
To hear and immediately grasp the **Heavenly Dao** (天之道),
this is **sagacity** (圣).

*"To see and know, this is **wisdom** (智)."*
To see and immediately grasp the reason for their conduct,
this is **wisdom** (智).

*"**Enlightened** (明明), this is **wisdom** (智)."*
**Wisdom** (智) is to infer what is unseen from what is seen.

*"**Resounding** (赫赫), this is **sagacity** (圣)."*
[This term] refers to the **Dao**’s [profound] resonance.

*"**Enlightened** (明明) below, **resounding** (赫赫) above" (明明在下，赫赫在上),*
this is what is meant.
**Enlightenment** (明) begins below, **resonance** (赫) begins above,
thus it is called **sagacity** and **wisdom** (圣智).

The **sagely ones** (圣人) know the **Heavenly Dao** (天之道).

To see a **virtuous one**, this is **enlightenment** (明).
To see and know, this is **wisdom** (智).

and the **Five Phases** (五行) are brought into harmony.
Harmony brings **music** (乐),
**music** (乐) brings **virtue/power** (德),
**virtue/power** (德) brings the flourishing of the realm and family.
The **Dao** of **King Wen** (文王) was thus.

*"**King Wen** (文王) above, his **virtue/power** (德) shone forth to **Heaven** (天)" (文王在上也，于昭于天),*
this is what is meant.

◆**[Explication 17]** *"To hear the **Dao** of the **junzi**, this is **perceptiveness** (聪)."*

this is **perceptiveness** (聪).
**Perceptiveness** (聪) is the **sagacity** (圣) hidden in the ears.

*"To hear and know, this is **sagacity** (圣)."*
To hear and immediately grasp the **Heavenly Dao** (天之道),
this is **sagacity** (圣).

*"The **sagely ones** (圣人) know the **Heavenly Dao** (天之道)."*
**Dao** (道) is what is spoken of.

*"To know and act accordingly, this is **righteousness** (义)."*
To know the **junzi**’s teachings and act in accordance with them,
this is the **qi** of **righteousness** (义).

*"To act accordingly and harmoniously, this is **virtue/power** (德)."*
**Harmony** (时) is **harmonization** (和);
**harmonization** (和) is **benevolent virtue/power** (惠德).

*"To see a **virtuous one**, this is **enlightenment** (明)."*
Though one sees the same, they alone resonate and discern the **virtuous one**,
this is **enlightenment** (明).
**Enlightenment** (明) is the **wisdom** (智) hidden in the eyes.
**Enlightenment** (明) brings the seeing of **virtuous ones** (贤人).

*"To see and know, this is **wisdom** (智)."*
One might ask: How so?
To immediately grasp what is seen and known,
this is **wisdom** (智).

*"To know and find peace in it, this is **benevolence** (仁)."*
To know the **junzi**’s teachings and rest peacefully therein,
this is the **qi** of **benevolence** (仁).

*"To find peace and reverence them, this is **propriety** (礼)."*
Having already found peace in them,
and yet again solemnly reverencing them,
this is the **qi** of **propriety** (礼).

[The **sagely ones** (圣人) resonate with the **Heavenly Dao** (天道).]

*"**Benevolence** (仁) is the source from which **propriety** (礼) and **music** (乐) arise."*
This is to say that **propriety** (礼) and **music** (乐) arise from **benevolence** (仁) and **righteousness** (义).

*"The **Five Phases** (五行) are brought into harmony, harmony brings **music** (乐)."*
**Harmony** (和) is like the **Five Sounds** (五声) in harmony.
**Music** (乐) is to speak of its flowing nature,
its natural and boundless resonance.
To **forget** (忘) the **boundaries** (塞),
this is the **virtue/power** (德) that is most complete.

*"With **virtue/power** (德), the realm and family flourish."*
The flourishing of the realm and family is to say that the **world** (天下) flourishes in **benevolence** (仁) and **righteousness** (义),
and to speak of its **resounding** (赫赫) **music** (乐).

*"**King Wen** (文王) above, his **virtue/power** (德) shone forth to **Heaven** (天),*
this is what is meant.
This is to say that his **great virtue/power** (大德) was fully realized.

**[Scripture 18]** To see and know, this is **wisdom** (智).」

To know and find peace in it, this is **virtue/power** (仁).
To find peace and act upon it, this is **righteousness** (义).
To act upon it with reverence, this is **ritual** (礼).
**Virtue/power** (仁), **righteousness** (义), and **ritual** (礼) are what **Dao/Way** (道) generates,
and the harmony of the **Four Conducts** (四行).

When harmonized, they align;
when aligned, they are good.

---
**[Explication 18]** *"To see and know, this is wisdom (智)."*
Seeing is with the eyes;
wisdom is to know what is seen and what is unseen.

*"To know and find peace in it, this is virtue/power (仁)."*
To know the **Dao/Way** of the **Noble One** (君子) and rest peacefully therein—this is the **qi** of **virtue/power** (仁气).

*"To find peace and act upon it, this is righteousness (义)."*
Having found peace, to act resolutely—this is the **qi** of **righteousness** (义气).

*"To act upon it with reverence, this is ritual (礼)."*
Having acted, to hold it with solemn reverence—this is the **qi** of **ritual** (礼气).

What is found peace in, acted upon, and held with reverence—this is the **Dao/Way of humanity** (人道).

*"**Virtue/power** (仁) [and **righteousness** (义)], **ritual** (礼) [and **wisdom** (智)] are what **Dao/Way** (道) generates."*
This means **ritual** (礼) and **wisdom** (智) arise from **virtue/power** (仁) and **righteousness** (义).

*"The harmony of the **Four Conducts** (四行)."*
This means harmonizing **virtue/power** (仁) and **righteousness** (义).

*"When harmonized, they align."*
Harmony is like the **Five Sounds** (五声) in accord.
Alignment is adherence to moderation, as if the heart were one—
to speak of abandoning the **Four Conducts** (四) while they align with the **good heart** (善心).

Alignment is the ultimate goodness.
*"When aligned, they are good."*
[The **Four Conducts** are] the great **Dao/Way** of humanity—
greatness is the **Dao/Way** of humanity’s [true] nature.

The *World’s Heir* says:
*"Humanity has a constant **Dao/Way**,
reaching [its] utmost limit."*

---
**[Scripture 19]** The **complexion** and **demeanor** are warm and responsive.
To exchange **heart-center** (中心) with others in joy—
the **heart-center** rejoices.

To extend this to brothers, this is **affection** (戚).
To **affection** and trust them, this is **kinship** (亲).
To **kinship** and deepen it, this is **love** (爱).
To love one’s father, and thereby extend love to others—this is **virtue/power** (仁).

---
**[Explication 19]** *"The **complexion** and **demeanor** are warm and responsive,"*
Warm and responsive is diligent and modest,
able to act with warmth and responsiveness.
Those who can act with warmth and responsiveness
first bring joy to the **heart-center**,
and when the **heart-center** rejoices,
the **complexion** and **demeanor** become warm,
to bring joy and responsiveness.

*"To exchange **heart-center** with others in joy,"*
[The **heart-center**] is like a wheel turning smoothly...

*"The **heart-center** rejoices,"*
...this is the **heart-center**’s own joy.
If one lacks joy in the **heart-center**,
they do not extend it to brothers.

*"To extend this to brothers, this is **affection** (戚),"*
This means to extend the joy of the **heart-center** to brothers
and be able to feel **affection** (戚).

Brothers who cannot get along
are not without the capacity for joy in the **heart-center**—
they simply do not extend it to brothers.

*"To **affection** and trust them, this is **kinship** (亲),"*
This means to trust their **essence** (体).
Sever their limbs, give them the world—
they would not do it.
Sever their brothers’ limbs, give them the world—
they would not hesitate;
this is to say that trust is already established.

Trust their **essence** and only then can they be close.

*"To **kinship** and deepen it, this is **love** (爱),"*
To deepen is to make it thick—
to thicken **kinship** and only then can they love one another.

*"To love one’s father, and thereby extend love to others—this is **virtue/power** (仁),"*
This means to love one’s father and then extend it to others.
To love one’s father while killing one’s neighbor’s child
cannot yet be called **virtue/power** (仁).

---
**[Scripture 20]** The **heart-center** speaks clearly and acts uprightly—this is **uprightness** (直).
To **uprightness** and persist in it—this is **boldness** (肆).
To **boldness** without fearing the powerful—this is **resolute** (果).
Not to harm the **Great Dao/Way** for the sake of the **small Dao/Way**—this is **simplicity** (简).
To commit great crimes and punish them greatly—this is **conduct** (行).
To honor the noble—this is to equalize reverence for the worthy—this is **righteousness** (义).

「**[Explanation 20]** *"The heart-center speaks clearly and acts uprightly—this is **uprightness** (直),"*
If all the world’s delicious foods were here,
and one sighed and offered them,
the heart-center would not be confused.
To despise one who sighs and does not accept the sigh,
yet act uprightly—this is **uprightness** (直).

*"To **uprightness** and persist in it—this is **boldness** (肆)."*
**Boldness** (肆) is the persistence of **uprightness** (直).
**Uprightness** (直) is [the ability to] esteem the noble without **boldness** (肆).

*"To **boldness** without fearing the powerful—this is **resolute** (果)."*
The powerful are those with **courageous strength** (勇力).
If one does not fear them,
and does not hesitate in one’s heart
when punishing them with **courageous strength** (勇力),
then this is **resolute** (果).

*"Not to harm the **Great Dao/Way** for the sake of the **small Dao/Way**—this is **simplicity** (简),"*
**Simplicity** (简) means
not harming **great love** (大爱) for the sake of **small love** (小爱),
not harming **great righteousness** (大义) for the sake of **small righteousness** (小义).
To see them alive and not eat their dead bodies,
to execute the offender when honoring one’s parents—
this is **simplicity** (简).

*"To commit great crimes and punish them greatly—this is **conduct** (行),"*
If there is no crime yet one kills,
or if there is death yet one does not punish—
then one does not know the **Dao/Way** of punishing people,
and thus it is called **conduct** (行).

*"To honor the noble—this is to equalize reverence for the worthy—this is **righteousness** (义)."*
To honor the noble means
to esteem the **noble** (众贵) without partiality.
The worthy are honored,
the long-serving are promoted,
the near are cherished,
and ranks are awarded fairly—
this is to select the worthy without bias.
To equalize reverence for the worthy—
this is **righteousness** (义).
To honor the worthy means
to regard them as equals,
to select them fairly,
and to place them in high positions.
This is not because of their nobility,
but because of **righteousness** (义).
If one honors the noble yet does not esteem the worthy,
it cannot yet be called **righteousness** (义).

---

**[Scripture 21]** To use one’s **external heart-center** (外心) in interactions with others—this is **distant** (远).
To **distant** yet maintain **solemn composure** (庄)—this is **reverence** (敬).
To **reverence** without relenting—this is **austerity** (严).
To **austerity** with **awed restraint** (畏)—this is **esteem** (尊).
To **esteem** without arrogance—this is **deference** (恭).
To **deference** with broad exchanges—this is **ritual propriety** (礼).

**[Explanation 21]** *"To use one’s **external heart-center** (外心) in interactions with others—this is **distant** (远),"*
The **external heart-center** (外心) is not a separate mind.
It is the same mind,
yet some call it **external heart-center** (外心),
and some call it **heart-center** (中心).
The **heart-center** (中心) is the **confused** (媆然) one;
the **external heart-center** (外心) is the **unclouded** (廓然) one,
speaking of this mind when interacting with others at a distance.

*"To **distant** yet maintain **solemn composure** (庄)—this is **reverence** (敬),"*
**Reverence** (敬) is [the state of] *mouth-to-mouth* [communication].
